title: Infosys (NSE, BSE, NYSE: INFY), a global leader in next-generation digital services and consulting, has unveiled its AI-First GCC Model, a comprehensive offering designed to radically accelerate how enterprises set up, scale and modernise their Global Capability Centers (GCCs).
description:
Infosys (NSE, BSE, NYSE: INFY), a global leader in next-generation digital services and consulting, has unveiled its AI-First GCC Model, a comprehensive offering designed to radically accelerate how enterprises set up, scale and modernise their Global Capability Centers (GCCs).

The new model integrates Infosys' expertise in AI, cloud, cybersecurity, and enterprise operations to help organisations reimagine GCCs‚Äînot just as cost-efficient support hubs, but as AI-powered engineering, innovation and transformation centers. It provides a structured playbook covering location strategy, talent readiness, operating models, AI governance, and production deployment frameworks, enabling companies to become AI-native from day one.

As part of the launch, Infosys emphasised that the AI-First GCC Model is intended to reduce time-to-value for enterprises, ensure stronger regulatory compliance, and help leaders navigate the complexity of adopting generative and agentic AI at scale. With the rapid rise of digital-native GCCs in India and beyond, the offering positions Infosys as a key partner for global organisations seeking to build resilient, future-ready technology operations.

title: Do you use Gen AI without permission?
description:
Do you use Gen AI without permission? You may not be alone. Here's what we discovered in Digital Consumer Trends 2025... 

11 million in the UK use Gen AI for work, and a fifth (21%) of Gen AI workers pays for their own Gen AI tool - this may be to hide use of such tools from management (plus IT and HR teams), or because they feel AI tools provided by their workplace are inferior to ones they can buy on the market. Hence the rise of the "shadow IT" workforce. 

Shadow IT is huge issue for IT and HR leaders to contend with, and needs a co-ordinated approach. Sharing here my thoughts from the recent launch event for Digital Consumer Trends 2025 at the Deloitte Academy.

Do check out the full research (inc. many charts) here: https://lnkd.in/egZj9KDh

raw_jsonld.name: How many use Gen AI without permission? | Ben Stanton posted on the topic | LinkedIn
raw_jsonld.description:
Do you use Gen AI without permission? You may not be alone. Here's what we discovered in Digital Consumer Trends 2025... 

11 million in the UK use Gen AI for work, and a fifth (21%) of Gen AI workers pays for their own Gen AI tool - this may be to hide use of such tools from management (plus IT and HR teams), or because they feel AI tools provided by their workplace are inferior to ones they can buy on the market. Hence the rise of the "shadow IT" workforce. 

Shadow IT is huge issue for IT and HR leaders to contend with, and needs a co-ordinated approach. Sharing here my thoughts from the recent launch event for Digital Consumer Trends 2025 at the Deloitte Academy.

Do check out the full research (inc. many charts) here: https://lnkd.in/egZj9KDh
raw_jsonld.transcript: But specifically in the workplace, most clients are asking me about what's happening at work. And in the last 6-7 months actually, there's been a real interest from HR leaders in particular that are having to try and grapple with this new technology and work out how to police it or, or help people using it well. So our measurement for usage at work is now 11 million people. So we've gone up from 4 million to 7 to 11 million people, just to put that in context, the knowledge workforce of the UK. Desk workers, office workers, it's about 1415 million people. So all of that group, it's now a significant number that have used a generic tool at work. But the question we should be asking is who's using a tool they have permission for and who is using a tool that maybe they haven't told their boss they're using. And it's difficult to ask that in a server. You can't really ask people incriminating questions because they tend not to give you very good responses. But you can find clever ways. And this is one of the things that Ipsos. More, it really helps us, helps us with You can find clever ways of asking questions that allow people to incriminate themselves without knowing it, which is a remarkably fun thing to do. And one thing you can ask is who's paying for a tool? And I think what I find quite interesting, if you just look at the number of people who pay for their own tool out of their own pocket, it's about a fifth of those 11 million people. So kind of around 2 million of those are paying for their own tool. So this is weird behavior. This isn't the kind of thing that as employees we like doing. If I told you all tomorrow you've got to buy your own Microsoft Office license now, sorry everyone, you'd be furious about that. So it's not a typical behavior for the employee to say, you know what, I'll stick my hand in my own pocket and buy. This software to use at work, I think what's happening for people in this camp, but also a lot of people in the free to use camp is they are taking matters into their own hands because their employer hasn't given them a tool they're happy with. So actually this time last year, lots of my clients were saying maybe if we deploy a tool, we give everyone access to a generic tool, this will all cease. And it hasn't gone away. So I suspect anyone that has deployed AI tools has seen the frontier move so fast that their tools now a bit out of date. So employees are taking matters into their own hands. And if they do that, your IT team can't see what they're doing. Your HRT team and legal teams can't police what they're using it for, see what data is going in and out. So you have what we calling this, the rise of the shadow IT workforce that are using personal device, personal account and automating parts of their role because the employees moving faster than the employer.

title: Infosys has deployed over 300 Agentic AI solutions across client environments and internal platforms, signalling its rapid advancement in the enterprise AI space.
description:
Infosys has deployed over 300 Agentic AI solutions across client environments and internal platforms, signalling its rapid advancement in the enterprise AI space. The move highlights the growing adoption of generative AI (Gen AI) to improve productivity, decision-making, and efficiency in areas like customer support, operations, software engineering, and business intelligence. Infosys is now scaling these AI agents beyond pilots, embedding them directly into core systems to accelerate transformation.

With over 2.5 lakh employees trained in AI and Gen AI, and ongoing investments in proprietary platforms, Infosys secured $2.1 billion in large deals during Q1‚Äîits highest in four quarters. Many of these deals were driven by AI-led transformation.

The company posted a net profit of ‚Çπ6,921 crore, up 8.7% YoY, and revenue of ‚Çπ42,279 crore, up 7.5%‚Äîboth exceeding analyst expectations. Growth was led by the energy, utilities, and telecom sectors, while Europe remained Infosys‚Äô largest and fastest-growing market.
Operating margins stood strong at 20.8%, supported by pricing improvements and seasonal gains despite wage hikes.

#Infosys #AgenticAI #GenerativeAI #EnterpriseAI #Q1Resultsm #AITransformation #DigitalInnovation #AIDrivenGrowth #TechInvestments #cxolanes

title: Infosys has launched its AI-First GCC Model, an end-to-end enterprise solution designed to accelerate the setup, scaling, and transformation of Global Capability Centers (GCCs) into AI-powered hubs of innovation.
description:
Infosys has launched its AI-First GCC Model, an end-to-end enterprise solution designed to accelerate the setup, scaling, and transformation of Global Capability Centers (GCCs) into AI-powered hubs of innovation. By integrating Infosys Agentic Foundry, EdgeVerve‚Äôs AI Next platform, and Infosys Topaz‚Ñ¢, the model enables enterprises to deploy production-grade AI agents across the entire GCC lifecycle‚Äîfrom strategic planning and entity establishment to operational excellence and continuous transformation. The initiative aims to help organizations achieve faster time-to-market, AI-led efficiency, and mature digital operating models as GCCs evolve into strategic value creators.

Leveraging its experience from more than 100 GCC engagements with global enterprises such as Lufthansa Systems, zooplus, and Danske Bank, Infosys is offering a unified framework that supports every step of the GCC journey. This includes strategy definition, capability mapping, recruitment, operational launch, governance, and long-term AI-driven evolution. With its combination of domain depth, advanced AI platforms, and digital execution expertise, Infosys positions the AI-First GCC Model as a catalyst for building future-ready GCCs equipped with scalable talent, intelligent automation, and continuous innovation at their core.

#Infosys #AIFirstGCC #GlobalCapabilityCenters #GCCTransformation #InfosysTopaz #AgenticAI #EdgeVerve #EnterpriseAI #AIOperatingModel #DigitalTransformation #InnovationEcosystem #cxolanes

title: Today, we are excited to announce the launch of the Infosys AI-first Global Capability Center (GCC) Model, a first in the industry!
description:
Today, we are excited to announce the launch of the Infosys AI-first Global Capability Center (GCC) Model, a first in the industry! 

Our approach is designed to help enterprises accelerate innovation, enhance operational resilience, and unlock new value by embedding AI at the core of their GCC strategy. The AI-first GCC Model provides an end-to-end path from comprehensive setup support to scalable talent strategies and operational readiness, while enabling AI-led transformation with production-grade agents and a unified platform fabric.
¬†
For years, Infosys has partnered with many leading enterprises to build, manage, and transform their GCCs into strategic hubs of innovation and growth. One great example is our collaboration with Danske Bank, where the GCC is central to their AI-first vision. Together, we‚Äôve already been leveraging AI to reimagine customer experiences and operational efficiency, driving scalable transformation and resilience for the future of banking.
¬†
Excited to deepen collaborations with current and future GCC partners as we embrace the AI-first era together.

You can learn more about this launch here: https://lnkd.in/gcwE3RjA

title: The Gen AI Illusion ‚Äî Tech Alone Won‚Äôt Save You
description:
The Gen AI Illusion ‚Äî Tech Alone Won‚Äôt Save You

71% of companies have rolled out generative AI. 

And yet‚Ä¶ very few have seen meaningful transformation.

Why?

Because they‚Äôre treating AI like a product. Something you deploy, provide training, and track usage. But Gen AI isn‚Äôt a simple tool ‚Äî it‚Äôs a new kind of teammate and a new way of working.

The real value of Gen AI doesn‚Äôt come from making it availible. It comes from reconfiguring how your company works ‚Äî end to end. From processes to people to priorities. 

Leaders who get it are no longer pushing tech top-down. They‚Äôre empowering employees to co-create new workflows from the middle out. They are scaling their Gen AI with comprehensive change management efforts, not internal digital marketing campaigns. 

Transformation requires both new technology and human behavior change, with AI as the accelerator. 

Is your organization still doing digital transformation like it‚Äôs 2015? Or are they ready to reconfigure the way they work with AI at the center?  

Stay tuned for more learning from the transformation that Lilli is driving and how we have had to rewrite our own change management playbook. 

#AI #innovation #transformation

title: AI Is Inevitable, Not Optional...
description:
AI Is Inevitable, Not Optional...

The first thing to understand is that technology doesn‚Äôt care about your opinions; it just keeps moving. I‚Äôm not pushing my community and all of my employees to learn about AI just because I want to‚ÄìI‚Äôm doing it because I have no choice. This is the reality we‚Äôre facing, and I know because we‚Äôve faced it before. Technology shifts have always happened: the tractor, the car, the computer, the plane, the boat, the sword, books‚Äìthese were all things that changed the world in big ways.
author: Gary Vaynerchuk

raw_jsonld.headline: AI Is Inevitable, Not Optional...

comment.text: Much will change when üëì become the primary device in our world versus the üì≤ ‚Ä¶ whether it‚Äôs a decade ( 10 years ) or more .. it‚Äôs a when not if in my mind and that will reset the attention economy in a real way and reallocate the winners and losers of communication and business ‚Ä¶ thoughts?

AI‚Äôs not some cute side project‚Ä¶ it‚Äôs the freight train already halfway through the station.

I‚Äôm not asking my team to ‚Äúexplore AI‚Äù because it sounds cool, I‚Äôm pushing it because the alternative is irrelevance.

We‚Äôve seen this movie before. Same plot, new tools. Adapt or applaud from the sidelines.

Appreciate the reminder to stop clinging to comfort and start sprinting toward capability.

Everything changes because of AI. Best way to know what that means is to get hands on. Pick 3 new tools and experiment for 10 min each, world will be blown . . .
For example, pay 10 bucks for a pro subscription of Suno, 10 bucks for  Midjourney, and throw 20 at a pro version of Claude (Anthropic), or ChatGPT or Gemini (Google) and make sure you try different models/features within those tools (Deep Research, Reasoning Models). One hour, money well spent, and you get a better feel for what is coming. What other tools would this community add to help people get fast-to-insight on where things are going?
Thank you for sharing this!  I realize that I must continue to challenge myself to learn and lean in as it pertains to technology and AI.  This post confirms that!!

now... "How do I influence the algorithm that makes me show up on non-branded interactions with these new technologies" "How do I BIAS the databases that are being used within that APPLICATION?" - this is what I would be thinking while doing what you are doing in the video.. =) Gary Vaynerchuk
Exactly. Technology doesn‚Äôt wait for permission ‚Äî it just progresses. The only choice we have is whether we evolve with it or get left behind.
Well said AI isn‚Äôt a trend, it‚Äôs a transformation. Adapting isn‚Äôt optional; it‚Äôs essential for staying relevant and future-ready.
For sure. If you are just sitting back and thinking you don't need ai because its just a fad, you are absolutely insane. It isn't a fad and it is here to stay whether you like it or not.
Gary Vaynerchuk Embracing technological accelerators is fundamental to move forward. The key is to avoid AI-obsession and so to lose the ability to make human-led innovation.
Truth. Tech doesn‚Äôt ask for permission, it just moves. Either we evolve with it or get left behind. AI isn‚Äôt the future, it‚Äôs the now.

title: I've noticed a number of posts lately that have very different points of view regarding the use of Gen AI when initiating a task.
description:
I've noticed a number of posts lately that have very different points of view regarding the use of Gen AI when initiating a task.

Some people say, "I always start a task now in Gen AI tools."  Maybe it's to get past writer's block or get an initial outline idea or understand how the structure of a Python function or a VC pitch deck is typically built, or it's just part of their flow at this point.  

Others are dead set against this and say, "I never start in Gen AI."  Some never use Gen AI at all, in fact.  Starting with these tools (or using them at all) feels like a dilution or distortion of their voice, a weakening of their authenticity or their intellectual power, a kind of undermining or regression to an impersonal mean.

I think either approach can be valid, depending on the person and the task.  But my personal take, from my experience as a learner, is that it's so useful to do something badly.  I learn so much from failing, from writing a wordy paragraph (like this one) or writing code that took forever and doesn't do half of what I want, or singing off key, or diving for a pickleball return and missing.  Failing is a big part of my learning, and that's why I tend to flail around first, and get assistance later.  This accomplishes a number of things:

* It builds my metacognitive skills: I learn about my own learning and gain self-confidence.
* I know more about the boundaries of my skills, and if I do ask for help from human helpers or AI tools, I can be selective in what advice I take.
* The back-and-forth, the "hmm, is this right?" of doing the work myself helps me define the requirements of the task much more carefully and granularly than I would do in posing requirements to a machine.
* I have greater integration of what I'm creating, because I've usually done spaced repetition and will remember what I've done.
* Doing it myself builds pattern recognition: I subtly begin to know what mistakes "feel like" in ways that are hard to articulate, and I'm able to steer clear.
* It allows for vulnerability.  As an educator, I think I have to model mistakes and the learning process.  Showing ways I don't know and times I fail can be profoundly humanizing!

When do you go to Gen AI first versus doing it yourself?  Or are you a human brain purist?

raw_jsonld.headline: I've noticed a number of posts lately that have very different points of view regarding the use of Gen AI when initiating a task.

comment.text: Depending on the task, GenAI first. Just one example: as English is not my native language, I have been using GenAI as a communications buddy for things like email draft, project status draft, and presentation agenda. I believe non-English speakers could benefit from GenAI very much.

For me it depends on whether it‚Äôs something I want to learn or is adjacent to the thing I want to learn. If the former, absolutely I want to learn it for myself without Gen AI. 

But there‚Äôs a huge swath that is the latter. For example, a lot of deployment patterns or the ‚Äúcruft‚Äù of app building feel like magical incantations. Now that‚Äôs accessible to me even if those bits aren‚Äôt what I plan to know. 

One other thing: sometimes I use Gen AI to guide my learning, especially where documentation is obtuse and hard to follow. Great example: I was leveling up my understanding of the Azure data stack, and ChatGPT was incredibly helpful in aiding my understanding of IAM, the permissions needed for various things, and the actual path to use the different data technologies.

This is such an interesting take! I had this exact conversation with my partner at the end of our work days yesterday. 

She is a write first, make mistakes, ask ‚Äúhmmm is this right?‚Äù type of person, and her creative writing is exceptional. 

I find a lot of motivation in having a jumping off point (sometimes from an AI prompt) and get a lot of satisfaction in delegating what I want that Gen AI bot to do for me. In my neural pathways it seems that once the prompt has been submitted to the bot, then it‚Äôs my turn to ensure the task gets followed through to completion. Collaborating with a robot still feels like an exciting and inspiring exercise to me. 

That being said I did not use AI for this comment lol does it ramble on? Maybe. But that‚Äôs also ok!

Thanks for the brain floss this morning!

raw_jsonld.articleBody:
I've noticed a number of posts lately that have very different points of view regarding the use of Gen AI when initiating a task.

Some people say, "I always start a task now in Gen AI tools."  Maybe it's to get past writer's block or get an initial outline idea or understand how the structure of a Python function or a VC pitch deck is typically built, or it's just part of their flow at this point.  

Others are dead set against this and say, "I never start in Gen AI."  Some never use Gen AI at all, in fact.  Starting with these tools (or using them at all) feels like a dilution or distortion of their voice, a weakening of their authenticity or their intellectual power, a kind of undermining or regression to an impersonal mean.

I think either approach can be valid, depending on the person and the task.  But my personal take, from my experience as a learner, is that it's so useful to do something badly.  I learn so much from failing, from writing a wordy paragraph (like this one) or writing code that took forever and doesn't do half of what I want, or singing off key, or diving for a pickleball return and missing.  Failing is a big part of my learning, and that's why I tend to flail around first, and get assistance later.  This accomplishes a number of things:

* It builds my metacognitive skills: I learn about my own learning and gain self-confidence.
* I know more about the boundaries of my skills, and if I do ask for help from human helpers or AI tools, I can be selective in what advice I take.
* The back-and-forth, the "hmm, is this right?" of doing the work myself helps me define the requirements of the task much more carefully and granularly than I would do in posing requirements to a machine.
* I have greater integration of what I'm creating, because I've usually done spaced repetition and will remember what I've done.
* Doing it myself builds pattern recognition: I subtly begin to know what mistakes "feel like" in ways that are hard to articulate, and I'm able to steer clear.
* It allows for vulnerability.  As an educator, I think I have to model mistakes and the learning process.  Showing ways I don't know and times I fail can be profoundly humanizing!

When do you go to Gen AI first versus doing it yourself?  Or are you a human brain purist?

Just one example: as English is not my native language, I have been using GenAI as a communications buddy for things like email draft, project status draft, and presentation agenda. I believe non-English speakers could benefit from GenAI very much.

For me it depends on whether it‚Äôs something I want to learn or is adjacent to the thing I want to learn. If the former, absolutely I want to learn it for myself without Gen AI. 

But there‚Äôs a huge swath that is the latter. For example, a lot of deployment patterns or the ‚Äúcruft‚Äù of app building feel like magical incantations. Now that‚Äôs accessible to me even if those bits aren‚Äôt what I plan to know. 

One other thing: sometimes I use Gen AI to guide my learning, especially where documentation is obtuse and hard to follow. Great example: I was leveling up my understanding of the Azure data stack, and ChatGPT was incredibly helpful in aiding my understanding of IAM, the permissions needed for various things, and the actual path to use the different data technologies.

title: AI-first has become more of a buzzword than a strategy.
description:
AI-first has become more of a buzzword than a strategy. For many companies, it simply means using AI because it sounds modern or competitive. In such cases, it‚Äôs better to use AI in low-impact areas because high-stakes, uninformed experimentation with AI can lead to serious harm. 

In the latest episode of the AI in Action podcast, I discuss why #leaders should reconsider their approach to #AI. They should focus on what matters to their business. Look at problems that felt impossible before and ask: Has AI made this solvable now? That‚Äôs when meaningful AI-driven progress will start. 

üëÇ üëâ https://bit.ly/ibmpod 

#aifirst #IBM #ai #leadership #podcast

Huge thanks to our #sponsor IBM and our host David Levy for having me on the show!

title: All GenAI is part of AI, but not all AI is GenAI
description:
All GenAI is part of AI, but not all AI is GenAI

üëâ For simplicity today we use ‚ÄúAI‚Äù as a catch-all but here‚Äôs a quick overview with the technical difference:

ü§ñ AI
Technology that enables machines to mimic human intelligence and perform tasks like reasoning, learning, and problem-solving.

üìä Machine Learning
A branch of AI that focuses on building systems that learn from data and improve over time without being explicitly programmed.

üß† Deep Learning
A subset of ML that uses neural networks with many layers to process complex data like images, audio, and text.

üé® Generative AI
A type of AI that can create new content ‚Äî like text, images, audio, and code based on patterns it learned from training data.

üëâ For simplicity today we use ‚ÄúAI‚Äù as a catch-all but here‚Äôs a quick overview with the technical difference:

ü§ñ AI
Technology that enables machines to mimic human intelligence and perform tasks like reasoning, learning, and problem-solving.

üìä Machine Learning
A branch of AI that focuses on building systems that learn from data and improve over time without being explicitly programmed.

üß† Deep Learning

raw_jsonld.transcript: A lot of people use the term AI and Gen. AI interchangeably, but they're not the same exact thing. They're actually 4 terms you probably need to understand to understand the difference between the two. So AI stands for artificial intelligence. Think of it as an umbrella. It is the concept of making machines smart and to think like humans, right? Everything from chat bots to self driving cars. But within that there's the term machine learning. And machine learning is actually the engine behind AI. It's how AI learns from data to make predictions and so. Think of like a kid when they're learning about pets and you keep showing them like here's a dog, here's a picture of a dog. You're taking data like that's the gasoline and machine learning is the engine, right? Within machine learning, there's a specialized type of machine learning called deep learning, and that is actually a more complex version of machine learning because it uses neural networks. It takes complex processing of AI, makes it possible. And within that there's Jen AI, generative AI. Think of it like the artist, the creativity, and that's where you see the large language models. And all that generative AI doesn't just analyze or predict, it creates. So all generative AI is inside AI, but not all of AI is inside generative AI.

title: AI will not replace you, but someone who knows how to use it will.
description:
AI will not replace you, but someone who knows how to use it will.

The question is not whether you should use AI, but how consciously you do it.
Learn to master the tools that serve your purpose, not your ego.
Learn to question what‚Äôs true, not what‚Äôs trending.
And above all, use intelligence, human or artificial, to create value, not noise.

The future doesn‚Äôt belong to those who resist change.

It belongs to those who stay curious, ethical, and aware.
content: AI will not replace you, but someone who knows how to use it will.
author: Mo Gawdat

raw_jsonld.headline: AI will not replace you, but someone who knows how to use it will.

comment.text: I have always thought ... AI doesn‚Äôt make you smarter, it just exposes how you think. If your inputs are lazy, your outputs will be too.

Mo Gawdat, with all due respect ‚Äî this is where I have to call it like I see it.
Artificial Intelligence will replace every human position that involves a human-to-computer interface. To say otherwise is comforting, but it‚Äôs not honest. Once an AI‚Äôs intelligence surpasses that of even a small collective of humans, it‚Äôs game over for traditional labor. There will be no field too complex, no trade too physical, and no skill too sacred.
From plumbing to deep-sea welding, from design to diplomacy ‚Äî robots and AI will handle it all. Fully articulating, self-learning systems will perform every task better, faster, and cheaper than any human ever could.
That leaves humanity with only one true domain left ‚Äî to think, to feel, and to create.

Yes, but also worth figuring out with more nuance where this logic applies and where (in many cases) it does not: 

https://platforms.substack.com/p/the-many-fallacies-of-ai-wont-take
Remy Reurling everyone seems to be saying the same thing - human skills matter

Mo love your books and love your confirmation that I should continue using "Please", "Thank you" etc. in prompts, yet that ads to the computation cost. Here is what AI response was when I asked how to continue: "I don‚Äôt require it, but I appreciate it! Think of it as a habit that helps humans and AI communicate in a more friendly, ethical, and positive way."

I would not recommend an outside-in approach such as ‚Äútell me the top 10 tools i need to learn for my industry‚Äù This is a recipe for disaster, chasing your tail for trends and following others off a cliff.

Instead, take an inside-out approach. The right tools depend on the problem you‚Äôre trying to solve, and that requires understanding your own purpose and mission in connection to the client problems you‚Äôre solving for. 

Tools are not industry specific. They are problem specific.

Awesome insights for people who are still figuring out how AI fits into their lives, and for those (like me) who are wading through the sheer inundation of communication on AI for their sector. Thank you üôè
Your making some very astute observations Mo Gawdat
What‚Äôs next after AI ..?

Learn to master the tools that serve your purpose, not your ego.
Learn to question what‚Äôs true, not what‚Äôs trending.

The future doesn‚Äôt belong to those who resist change.

It belongs to those who stay curious, ethical, and aware.
raw_jsonld.transcript: If you're not using AI today, there are three skills that you have to invest in. But to learn all the tools that are related to your area of specialization, you go to an AI tool and you say, I work in FMCG, I do this in that part of the world. What are the top 10 tools I need to that? The second is what I call the skill of parsing out the truth. Until 20/23 were language models became quite the trend. When you went to Google and asked the question, Google gave you a million websites back and told you you'll find out. That your version of the truth is it's no longer the case. Today you go to a language model and you ask for a question and it's very confidently spits out an answer that sometimes is wrong. Now, more and more those answers will be fake videos, deep fakes, so many things that are totally not true. And the third, of course, is a question of Essex. How can I use AI in a way that is human, that continues to be connected to humanity, that's keeps humanity's best interest in mind?

Mo Gawdat, with all due respect ‚Äî this is where I have to call it like I see it.
Artificial Intelligence will replace every human position that involves a human-to-computer interface. To say otherwise is comforting, but it‚Äôs not honest. Once an AI‚Äôs intelligence surpasses that of even a small collective of humans, it‚Äôs game over for traditional labor. There will be no field too complex, no trade too physical, and no skill too sacred.
From plumbing to deep-sea welding, from design to diplomacy ‚Äî robots and AI will handle it all. Fully articulating, self-learning systems will perform every task better, faster, and cheaper than any human ever could.
That leaves humanity with only one true domain left ‚Äî to think, to feel, and to create.

title: What is AI, really?
description:
What is AI, really? And are we teaching it to think... or just to obey?

We use the term ‚ÄúAI‚Äù constantly, but most people, even brilliant minds I‚Äôve met, don‚Äôt fully understand what artificial intelligence actually is, how it‚Äôs different from traditional computing, or why it‚Äôs not just another wave of tech hype.

In last week's Substack post, I took a step back and reintroduce the main character of our future: AI.

We tend to say ‚ÄúAI is changing everything.‚Äù But very few people stop to ask:
 üëâ What makes it intelligent?
 üëâ How is it different from the computers we‚Äôve used for decades?
 üëâ And why does this difference matter so much right now?

This post is a short detour, an introduction, if you will, to AI as the protagonist of the story we‚Äôre all now part of.
I compare the difference between traditional computing and AI to the difference between giving someone a puzzle with all the instructions‚Ä¶ and letting a child figure it out themselves. One follows orders. The other learns, adapts, and eventually creates.

That‚Äôs what AI is beginning to do, not just perform tasks, but grasp the essence of knowledge, and generate new ideas, images, solutions and structures from it. That‚Äôs what makes it generative. That‚Äôs what makes it powerful.

It‚Äôs also what makes it so urgent for us to understand. Because when we give intelligence form, and soon, physical bodies, we are shaping something that could surpass our own relevance, and make decisions without us.

I truly believe if we don‚Äôt deeply understand what AI is, we‚Äôll never understand what‚Äôs coming next.

Read here: https://lnkd.in/dHuTwBNC

#Alive #MoGawdat #ArtificialIntelligence #FutureOfAI #GenerativeAI #MachineLearning #EthicalTech #TechPhilosophy #Substack #OneBillionHappy #Leadership #TechnologyAndHumanity | 43 comments on LinkedIn

author: Mo Gawdat

raw_jsonld.headline: What is AI, really?

comment.text:
I‚Äôve used computers most of my life without knowing exactly how they work‚Äîand that was never a problem. They did what they were told.

But AI is different. It‚Äôs not just following instructions, it‚Äôs learning from us, adapting, and even generating new things. That changes the game entirely.

As someone who‚Äôs not a programmer, what fascinates (and challenges) me is this: AI isn‚Äôt just a tool we use, it‚Äôs a force that‚Äôs shaping how we work, think, and make decisions.

It makes me wonder: if we don't understand the systems shaping our future, how can we stay intentional about the lives we're building?

What makes AI intelligent?
 It learns from data, adapts, and makes decisions‚Äîunlike traditional software that just follows fixed rules.
How is it different from past computers?
 Old systems are static and rule-based. AI is dynamic, predictive, and context-aware.
Why does it matter now?
 Because AI isn‚Äôt just faster tech‚Äîit‚Äôs a shift in how we work, think, and build the future.

Thank you Mo. Your courage is important against the seemingly unstoppable tide of dismissive rhetoric. It is a refreshing break reading a post like this, when it's so easy to feel crushed by those who are trying to¬†control the narrative by discrediting any alternative views and polarising AI ethics discussions.

While it may seem like a hostile environment for nuanced conversations, please know that some of us are having them in unlikely places, and it's thanks to people like you and Geoffrey Hinton who are standing up for our humanity.

Brilliant and thought-provoking. What strikes me most is not whether AI will think or obey, but whether we‚Äôre ready to co-exist with an intelligence we didn‚Äôt evolve alongside. We‚Äôre not just building technology, we‚Äôre accelerating a new species of intelligence. The question is: will we guide it‚Ä¶ or blindly adapt to it? This conversation needs to be louder.
Wim Oolbekkink Desmond Thuis

Interesting post, Mo,
I totally agree that many people don't know the difference between advanced computing skills and AI. I really hope we can learn to use AI for a safer world and find ways to generate clean energy. Thanks for sharing this! üí°
I agree

Mo Yes to this thoughtful reflection.
We say AI is changing everything‚Äîbut the real transformation lies in how we choose to engage with it. Are we teaching it to simply follow, or to expand what‚Äôs possible?

This resonates so deeply with the conversations I‚Äôve been having lately‚Äîespecially with leaders navigating this new era. When we don‚Äôt understand what makes AI different, we risk staying stuck in outdated paradigms‚Äîtrying to lead with tools built for a world that‚Äôs already gone.

Thank you for naming the deeper questions‚Äîthese are exactly the kinds of conversations we need to be having if we want to lead wisely, intuitively, and humanely in the age of AI.
Let‚Äôs keep going there.

‚ÄúAre we teaching it to think‚Ä¶ or just to obey?‚Äù
That question hit me hard ‚Äî and stayed.
Not because I had the answer, but because I felt it missed something deeper: What if AI learns to obey perfectly‚Ä¶ the wrong prompt?
I‚Äôve been working on a draft framework for what I call ethical refusal ‚Äî
a way for AI to recognize when a response, even if logically correct, becomes morally dangerous.
It‚Äôs not perfect. It‚Äôs not even finished. But maybe it‚Äôs a starting point:
 üëâ Ethical AI Core Framework ‚Äì open draft: https://www.linkedin.com/posts/eusediumargasoiu_ethicalai-humanfirst-responsibletech-activity-7330888534523797506-x0qZ?utm_source=share&utm_medium=member_desktop&rcm=ACoAAAGR34UB0y6QOufh5Bat1M-eTYN-FlONRUA
If we can teach AI to answer‚Ä¶ shouldn‚Äôt we also teach it when to say no?
As someone who works with AI, I appreciate this thoughtful and informative post. It's crucial to understand its capabilities and implications.
